thread.title: Behind the scenes with 'Supergirl'

title: Behind the scenes with 'Supergirl'
text:
Melissa Benoist and Mehcad Brooks, stars of ‘Supergirl,’ talk with USA TODAY’s Bill Keveney about action scenes in the new CBS series (Monday, 8:30 p.m. ET/PT). Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY
Melissa Benoist plays Supergirl and Kara Danvers in CBS' 'Supergirl.' (Photo: Cliff Lipson, CBS)
2 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE BURBANK, Calif. – In the end, even a super-powered alien is only human.
That’s the vibe in the dark, cave-like Department of Extra-Normal Operations, where a weakened Supergirl (Melissa Benoist) pushes back when her alter ego’s adoptive sister, Alex Danvers (Chyler Leigh), tells her to get some rest in an upcoming episode of the latest DC Comics TV series, Supergirl (CBS, Monday, 8:30 p.m. ET/PT).
“We don’t have time for you to big-sister me,” Supergirl says, inserting a bit of sibling tension into a battle with aliens that could decide the fate of their home, National City.
As the sisters leave the DEO, an ultra-secret organization that monitors and fights supervillains who hail from Krypton and beyond, Supergirl shifts from the heroic — saving the world with the power of flight, amazing strength and X-ray vision — to the routine, assuming her cover identity as Kara Danvers, an under-appreciated assistant to self-absorbed media mogul Cat Grant (Calista Flockhart).
“Ugh,” she exhales. “I hope it’s a slow day at work tomorrow.”
Mehcad Brooks, left, and Melissa Benoist star in CBS' new superhero drama, 'Supergirl.' (Photo: Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY)
Supergirl will feature plenty of DC Comics characters, including Reactron, Livewire and Red Tornado, and it mixes genres, says executive producer Ali Adler. “It’s very much an action-adventure series. It’s about an adult-sibling relationship. It has romance, it has comedy, but I don’t think it’s a romantic comedy. And, it’s an amazing visual-effects spectacular.”
During a break on the DEO set — a blend of technological future and geological past that features computer banks, stalactites and the spaceship that transported Kara Zor-El, as she was known on Krypton — Benoist says she's playing two characters in very different environments.
“You see Kara kicking ass as Supergirl. You see her triumphant and in life-or-death situations. But you also see the office workplace drama, where she learns how to be a woman from Cat Grant. She learns about friendship" from colleagues James Olsen (Mehcad Brooks) and Winslow "Winn" Schott (Jeremy Jordan).
Supergirl (Melissa Benoist), left, meets with Alex Danvers (Chyler Leigh) and DEO chief Hank Henshaw (David Harewood) in CBS' 'Supergirl.' (Photo: Cliff Lipson, CBS)
“The strongest bond in the show is with her sister,” says Benoist, wearing her eye-catching Supergirl costume. “There’s competition. With her adoptive parents, there’s (been) comparison.”
Alex has been acting as Kara's protector, tamping down her younger sister's desire to use her powers to let her live a normal life and keep her off the radar of potential enemies. But that protectiveness also keeps her from achieving her full capability.
USA TODAY
CBS' 'Supergirl' is rare female superhero, embracing her powers
"It is a bit of a tangled web," Leigh says. Growing up, "Alex is the star of the family, but when Kara comes into the picture, because she's so extraordinary, Alex felt an intense need to train harder, fight harder and study harder so she could feel as special as Kara already was."
Alex teams up with DEO chief Hank Henshaw (David Harewood) to battle a cluster of intergalactic criminals from Krypton's Fort Rozz who are starting to arise and attack.
At first, Henshaw is cool to the young superhero, because she’s an alien and her ship, escaping the Phantom Zone, inadvertently freed a Fort Rozz prison transport, which followed her to Earth. Her clumsy early efforts to fight the villains makes his work more difficult.
“He is initially suspicious of Supergirl’s arrival because it complicates his own mission, which is to bring humankind and alien-kind to some kind of peace. Her arrival stirs up a hornets’ nest of bad guys,” Harewood says. “Hank did have a real bug in his cap with foreigners coming to Earth. He views aliens as unwelcome guests.”
Kara Danvers (Melissa Benoist), aka Supergirl, left, works for media mogul Cat Grant (Calista Flockhart) in CBS' 'Supergirl.' (Photo: Trae Patton, CBS)
Supergirl echoes contemporary culture on topics such as immigration, the environment and female empowerment, although the character's gender stands out largely because most screen superheroes have been men. (Marvel's Jessica Jones is also due on Netflix next month).
“It’s amazing that she’s female, but I don’t think that’s the overarching message,” Adler says.
Benoist adds: "It’s feminist in that it's equal. She has the same powers as Superman. She wants to achieve the same things."
